tripleo_validations/tripleo_validator.py.message:
We already have this argument in line 282.

--extra-vars should remain unchanged.
Is it possible to receive parsed_args.extra_vars as anything else than a list?
In that case we could drop the checks for type on lines 366 and 381.

parseractions.MultiKeyValueAction always returns a list of dict.

Ex: [{'var1': 'value1', 'var2': 'value2', 'var3': 'value3'}]

This condition would look better if split into two. That way we could avoid the \ and potentially raise proper exception. 

The way it is done now we will get NameError.

Or at least change the order to avoid unnecessary exception:

https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#boolean-operations-and-or-not

If you look at line 263 or 287, the default value for these two args is an empty list. So if not used in the command line, here 
parsed_args.extra_[env_]vars will exist and we will always be defaulted to an empty list.

The isinstance test is a leftover from when I was testing w/o defaulting to a []. Now it is useless!

What I mean is that the condition, as it is, doesn't serve any sensible purpose. 

The parsed_args.extra_vars is always going to be a list. Therefore a check on type is unnecessary, and for the very some reason the check for None is unnecessary, since it will always pass, as it always will be something else than None, a list.

My point was mostly along the lines of evaluation order. That is, if  the parsed_args.extra_vars didn't exits in the namespace (something checked by the second half of the conditional) the isinstance would throw a NameError, and the check for presence wouldn't be reached. Giving us an exception and rendering the second condition useless, as it would never get interpreted. 

But since, as you said, the type is always a list, we can just discard this and get a better result.

All the arguments are and will be present in the namespace and in the case of the extra_vars, it will be set to None if we don't use the default arg of the add_argument(...) method.

Namespace(extra_env_vars=[], extra_vars=None, extra_vars_file='', group=[], limit=None, plan=None, ssh_user='heat-admin', static_inventory='', validation_name=['check-ram'])

As for line 366-367:

This condition would look better if split into two. That way we could avoid the \ and potentially raise proper exception. 

The way it is done now we will get NameError.

Or at least change the order to avoid unnecessary exception:

https://docs.python.org/3/library/stdtypes.html#boolean-operations-and-or-not

tripleo_ansible/playbooks/cli-overcloud-.message: Would this work for fresh deployments if you hardcode it to 'UPDATE'?

so, this does'nt work.
Am I passing the var incorrectly?
Or is it br0ken even for https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/branch/master/common/deploy-steps.j2#L571 ?
But not sure if that's cleaned properly for nodes with old deleted deployments.
I guess it's the https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-ansible/blob/master/tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_network_config/tasks/main.yml#L105 that would be 'true'.

This works because the tripleo_network_config role add's a file with the return code of the os-net-config run.
If the file does not exist, i.e a new deployment it will always apply configuration. Also if the return code wasn't a "success" it will also re-run.

If ironic is used the server is re-imaged when provisioned, and preferably cleaned when unprovisioned (deleted deployment). In either case there should be no return code file present.

Deleting a deployment, and the redeploying to the same nodes without restoring the nodes with a pristine image will be unreliable in any case. Not just networking wise, deleting a deployment doesn't unconfigure any services/configuration on the nodes.

The standalone doc[1] (number 10) provide a script that can be used to clean-up, this would delete the os-net-config return code file ensuring things run again. But since the script doesn't revert changes in /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts the result are still unreliable, with or without this patch.


[1] https://docs.openstack.org/project-deploy-guide/tripleo-docs/latest/deployment/standalone.html#deploying-a-standalone-openstack-node

tools/document/validate_site_docs.sh.message: It seems you don't use this file at all. Why do you generate it?
oh, I see, it's just for filtering kustomize results. anyways kustomize is redundant here, so it should be removed.

Kustomize is not needed here. all of this work could be done via airshipctl phase render command like:
airshipctl config phase render {phase} -k NetworkCatalogue > networking.yaml
airshipctl config phase render {phase} -k VersionsCatalogue > versions.yaml
etc

I'm familiar with airshipctl slowness during rendering phases...  That's because we calculate bundles around 5-6 times. I believe airshipctl speed issues were addressed here https://review.opendev.org/c/airship/airshipctl/+/780500

We are trying to get away from third party tools in our CI jobs, that's why for example we are implementing a toolbox container for airshipctl where we can run another utilities.

My thought here was speed... this script is already very slow to run, and having to render each phase 3 times for filtering purposes adds a lot of extra overhead. The approach you outlined above is actually how I'd originally written this, but for example when run against initinfra-ephemeral phase, on my system it was 58839ms. Using the render-once + kustomize approach cut that down to 20133ms.

I'm happy to change it if using airshipctl is the preferred approach though.
Shouldn't we verify VariableCatalogue as well?

Validation will fail here if unknown keys / incorrect data types or formats violate the schema defined in the CRD for each catalogue type. Since there's no schema for VariableCatalogues, I don't think we can use the same approach. The original issue was to create structural schema CRDs for each VariableCatalogue type, but I think there's at least a couple left, like hosts, that haven't been done yet
We should think about possibility of validation such kinds like Clusterctl and VeriableCatalogues in the future anyway, I believe there is should be a way how to define schemas for them...
If catalogue resources won't get applied to k8s, is it a good approach to verify it server-side forcefully?
This should be addressed with the use of the --dry-run=client in L146
I believe catalogue types should be defined via variable to make it easier for append/modify types in the future and have one source of truth.
I believe there is no necessity to apply these resources and create persisting changes, flag --dry-run=client could be specified here.

i am strongly against using kustomize directly, these solutions only work for specific sites. If we need some functionality to extract data from the document model, it should be developed as part of airshipctl.

You should run airshipctl phase render -k NetworkCatalogue instead.

swift/cli/manage_shard_ranges.py.message: Oh cool, that's a different way of checking for complete and imcomplete paths. That makes me feel better about how we're dealing with gaps.
yep, all paths are continuous, so complete means they span the entire namespace
Cool, and we're dropping if there are. Sweet!
yes, I don't want to get embroiled in gap fixing while the known problems are overlaps of complete paths.

OK here we're checking that the chosen path is actually cleaved/active completely, the filter_states will actaully break when it hits a SR that isn't in the filter.

Cool I get it, nice. I guess we need to be sure they're sorted, but that shold be the case because of find_paths.

no, we're checking that there are no cleaved or active ranges further down the chosen path than the end of the first run of cleaved/active i.e.:

(active, active, active) is OK
(cleaved, cleaved, created) is OK
(cleaved, created, cleaved) is not OK (weird scenario, need human help)

So if it turns out that the top ranked path is an invalid solution, rather then just end, sholdn't we check the next ranked path, as it might actaully also be complete and correct?

Or are we just going to wait and hope that the cleaving/active states get better and run again later. I worry that there actually still is a good path but somehow our sorting picked something slightly broken.

these invalid solutions imply that the set of shard ranges is in a state that we do not anticipate, so for now I am inclined to bail out and let humans help.

The next best path will have cleaved to <= cleaved_upper so will fail for the same reasons as the chosen_path - there's a stray range in cleaved/active that is beyond cleaved_upper - we should probably investigate such a scenario and understand what happened.
I look forward to playing with this in the future sometime to add the graphviz stuff, I think that would look awesome not just as a tool but as a display in a control interface somewhere 😊

includes here will only find gaps and the start and end of the path right. Because it's only looking at the max and min.

Maybe we need to start using find_missing_ranges which does just this, see: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/781013

Which you're more the welcome to squash in.

paths don't have gaps, other than at the start and end w.r.t. the entire namespace. This is a fundamental: a path is always continuous but not necessarily complete. Also, if there is no gap in shard_ranges then there must exist a path that spans the entire namespace.

I'm adding this comment:

  # individual paths do not have gaps within them; if no path spans the
  # entire namespace then there must be a gap in the shard_ranges
Oh right, of course! As a path with a gap in the middle would then appear are 2 paths.. which isn't incorrect. That makes alot of sense!

Might be out of scope, but I wonder if we should at least print the gaps which could be passed back in the GapFoundException, because if we ever find outself in this situtaiton it would be what we'd need to know next for any investigations.

Though I guess this could be something we should see pretty easily through graph visualisation.
totally agree that would be the next thing we'd need, but I'd prefer to leave that for a follow on patch, since this patch is already large and has been hanging around for a long time 😊
Why must we use a json to provide the shard data? for are we expected to do a 'show | analyze'.

repair without a 'yes' does the same on a db as analyze does on json, so analyze is only here to cater for loading from json rather than a db.

I gave it the broad name 'analyze' because I can imagine it reporting other interesting properties in the future (like gaps, 'raggedness' etc??)

So, yes it is expected that it would be used with s-m-s-r show | s-m-s-r analyze.

It would be cool if analyze could accept either a db or a json file, particularly if it grows other features, but it's already beyond the immediate use case of repair, so maybe for follow-on. For now repeat without a yes gives us everything that analyze might for a db.

off-topic: I do think that a --dry-run option would be useful for repair and compact, to supress the 'yes?' prompt.
+1 always best to start with the simple approach. we can always optimise later.

Love what we're testing here, but not 100% sure about the name filter_state, as that in my mind implies eactly what the filter on the line below does. Ie, filter the path for all the ranges in the given state. But this isn't what filter_states does. Well not strictly, it does if you pass in 'allow_gaps'. Otherwise it walks the path of shardranges and stop when it first gets to a shardrange not in the states.

I just think the name doesn't suit. Maybe `walk_filter(states)` or reverse it and make the param tell us more on what we're doing: 

  cleaved_upper = acceptor_path.filter_states(states, walk_until=True)

And by default filter with gaps, as Id assume if you'd used a list and saids filter by state you'd expect all to have a list of ranges with that state (with gaps).

yep, I've been fretting about the name filter_states too. certainly agree that flipping the default might make sense. It's a such a handy method to have, but not easy to name!

update: rewrote it as something much simpler in next revision

I wonder if this could be moved somehow into sharder, as I'de love to use this for the graph visualiser, also it would be nice to have the same check/analyze/repair/fsck code for both the tool and the auto-sharder (once we integrate it).
that should be possible
good idea, rather then adding it here and there.
Did you just want to change repair to use path_to_file too, rather then doing this here? esp now that's it has a multifunctional name.

repair does use path_to_file, the remapping here is because the functions that load data from file expect args.input, which for some commands (replace?) is different to args.path_to_file, i.e. you'd write:


  s-m-s-r db_file replace json-file
  <path_to_file> <input> <command>

whereas you'd write:

  s-m-s-r json_file analyze

so I needed to map input->path_to_file

Not like it matters, but you don't have to comprehend the whole list, I think. If ranked_paths[0].includes(own_sr) then you have at least one. You're actually using this property of ranking just 3 lines below in acceptor_path = ranked_paths[0].
Done

Just thinking out loud, could we have 2 sharding shards? This could make it look like 2 cleaving has happened later in the path?

Oh except we are blocking it entirely if there is a SHARDING range. So what are we expecting here? FOUND, CREATED I guess, but don't both of those indicate something should be SHARDING?

In fact, doesn't something in the CLEAVED state means something "could" stil be sharding. Although CLEAVED does means it's happily in charge of it's namespace.

I guess it just means I don't expect this code to trigger much so long as we have the SHARDING bloc active at the start of the method.

The SHARDING guard does not cover own shard range. We *do* expect this code to execute when a container has stalled part way through because of overlaps. Roots (at least) fail audit if there are overlaps and therefore may not progress with cleaving. I'm pretty sure we've seen this in production.

But I am being defensive about not attempting repair if we know there are sharding *shards*.

Id expect donor ranges to have ACTIVE or cleaved states in it. But I guess we shouldn't get one beyond the accptor path. Unless maybe we've had a split-brain and a smaller side shards. When we come back together could it pick the bigger one (that maybe hasn't finished). but in that case what is the right solution? Picking the bigger not quite sharded path or the smaller.

I guess the set of ranges wouldn't even be accepted until sharding is comepleted so probably a moot point.

Ranking prefers complete paths and then cleaving_progress, so we'd choose the 'smaller' side (assuming you mean object count) if it has completed cleaving over the bigger one if it hasn't.

IIRC my thinking re. cleaving progress was to avoid choosing a path that weaved its way from cleaved to uncleaved and back again, because that presents the problem of making isolated inactive shard ranges retrospectively active (retrospectively w.r.t. the cleaving context cursor).  I wanted the good path to be representative of an 'expected' shard range set, so not have CLEAVED-CREATED-CLEAVED for example. It then made sense to choose the path that was most cleaved, to avoid the solution shrinking a CLEAVED range into a yet-to-be-cleaved range and figuring out what should then happen to the acceptor state.

To put it another way, I am trying to make it that acceptor states are at least as advanced as their donors, as far as CLEAVED and ACTIVE are concerned.

But, we're stumbling across the 'small replica shards (too) quickly' issue in several places (e.g. here, shrinking decisions), so more motivation to find a fix for that.

swift/container/backend.py.message: Okay, although once you have 3 of them, I'll ask for something like getattr(shard_ranges, '__iter__', None) perhaps.

swift/container/sharder.py.message:
Seems you've built it on the asusmption it can take any list of shards, and we can analyze it. Pretty cool, however, would we ever not want to run this on root containers. I mean if we are assuming root containers should have an idea of the state of all the shards. And shards themselves even if split brained while sharding, I'd assume would just shard themselves the best they can and then delete.

I guess I worry that if we somehow have a gap (missing first or last shard) we'd do work but still silently have a gap. Where as with the root container we know we're dealing with a full namespace range so missing MIN or MAX means we know we have a gap issue.

I like how the we can have layers of preferences in a how to rank paths. But not 100% I understand the rankings.. maybe it's too early on a Monday morning :P

Would love to discuss this somepoint this week :)

I think we need to decide how this code should work. Are we planning on using this on shards. Because I'd rather say we only use find_paths and rank_paths on root conatiners. If there is a split-brained shard, to be honest, who cares. Let it shard out and then let's clean it up from the root.

As such it doesn't search the full namespace (MIN - MAX) because we don't know if say MIN or MAX was missing. Oh I see now, we'd just pass in the root container SR for the first order sorting (complete path for span). Cool.

I'm not convinced fewer timestamps or timestamps in general should be the best sorting tool for the best path. I know in Swift we tend to win on latest. But a shard (who thinks they're root because they've been off for a while) will shard with a newer timestamp. Timestamp should be a sort, but a lower order sort in my opinon. (I do like how the latest is the last match nice touch) 😊 (Also sorry, I know some of these thoughts might not be applicable with auto-sharding turned off, but can't help it :P )

I think the best determination is object count. When sharding we're talking about the amount of data to split and move. Picking the path with the most objects doesn't account for if we have a path that has just sharded or shrunk or not. Because we could end up picking a path that has in essence reverted a sharding/cleave just to have to do that work again. Or a path that has a bunch of shards that have already been collapsed. I guess if we're just looking at ACTIVE shardranges then we "should" only be dealing with already sharded and shrunk paths. unless we have a snaphot of a time where before the SHRUNK has made it to the root (but to have both paths here, shrunk and unshrunk, as active at the same time seems impossible).

Sorry just trying to work through this all in my mind. Just haven't convinced myself it isn't impossible yet :P At a minimum I think object count should come above fewer timestamps (or maybe drop fewer timestamps all together). Though i'm probably missing something.

And I'm really worried about not dealing if gaps.. but I see we just drop it (in manage-shard-ranges) so that's cool. We can only focus on split-brains and come back to gaps later.. I just want to be sure the approach could be adapted for gaps rather then having to rewrite anything.

I really like how this is coming along :)

I'm also unsure about the relative ranking of timestamps vs object count. I put fewer-timestamps first thinking it would be 'tidy' to preserve one half of a split-brain decision over the other by choosing a one-timestamp-path, but 'tidiness' may not be a good metric! 😊

We could make it a little more complex and weight the two metrics, so if object counts are not too different then fewer timestamps wins, but if object counts are very different then more objects wins.

But we could just flip to prefer object count. Without a good reason to know *why* we'd make it more complex then we shouldn't.

Re. Gaps - IMHO gap fixing is definitely out of scope on *this* patch. AFAIK we haven't seen gaps. But I think there is a plausible way to add gap fixing into the workflow here - find paths -> *fix gappy paths* -> rank paths.

Still want to play with this. It's an awesome start and maybe good enough to always come to a valid solution, as the solution doesn't always need to be the best, but a concensous and a correct one. And maybe I sholdn't over think it.

I still want to have more of a play in my SAIO
Still not sure this should be the 3rd level of sorting, maybe this could go last? or atleast further down the list.
Done

I've been playing around and wonder if we need to take more of the threshold into account, I threw up a unit test to demonstrait: https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/781597

Because more timestamps are bad, in the test base I linked above, it actually would want to revert the sharded shard (which is the difference), meaning we'd need to shard all over again.

Happy for this to be a first pass though, because it's otherwise pretty cool way to choose by different priorities. I'll keep playing.

Maybe in a follow up, I could dust off my weigting algoritm to see how it'll go as one of the ranks above (the one the neg effects small and over container threshold shards, but otherwise but otherwise bases it of obj count) as it might be able to simply drop it as a replacement for path.object on line 431.

UPDATE: something like the calculate_range_weight in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/swift/+/749614/7/swift/container/sharder.py

ok, I see your point, maybe we can do better. Hard thing is going to be if we need to know the expected object counts *after* the repair is applied, because we cannot predict that with overlaps. But we could try to avoid already large shards.

swift/obj/expirer.py.message: Probably should be "success" to match other metric names.
we have more options for aggregation in graphing if we use a '.' as a separator.  Prior art is status code metrics in proxy logging.  Is there a justification for the '-'?
Yeah, I was mainly thinking about aggregation. I guess we could do dots, and have it always be successful.204 and exception.0 or something...

oic, error-status keeps the dots inline for doing a total aggregate on *this* metric

Is this metric relevant if the delete wasn't successful?

I feel like we'd want to exclude reclaim to get a better picture of "how quickly we're servicing expirations" - i'm less sure what kind of errors we'd get.

There are a few different ways I'd want to slice it:

* max lag time, excluding reclaims
* max lag time, only looking at success
* sum of success counts over sum of all counts
* sum of reclaim counts over sum of all counts

I'm *also* not sure what kinds of errors we'd get -- part of why I wanted to break out errors and exceptions as well as I could.

octavia/common/jinja/haproxy/combined_li.message: Does it mean that pool.alpn_protocol parameters are silently ignored in case of old haproxy?

I'm not sure I agree with silently ignoring a user requested configuration. This could cause data plane traffic errors when end-users explicitly want to communicate over, say, HTTP/2. It would be challenging for the load balancer owner and cloud operator to notice this configuration nuance, which would require inspecting the amphora. How is this feature different from other features that also require a newer amphora image?

For example, UDP was introduced in Rocky. When a user requests creation of an UDP listener:
1. the worker tries to create UDP listeners
2. the worker fails to create UDP listeners on Queens or older amphora images
3. the worker set ERROR provisioning status
4. the health manager failovers amphora where one of two things can happen:
4a. health manager boots up Rocky or newer amphora image, leading to successful recovery or...
4b. health manager still boots a Queens or older amphora image, leading to failover error

Are you proposing changing the way all new features requiring newer amphora images are dealt?

The difference here is the implementation. The way the ALPN for pools was implemented is that it adds the "alpn" option to the haproxy configuration even if a user didn't not select the feature. It inserts the "default".
This default will cause all non-HAProxy 1.9 or newer amphora to fail, potentially into a failed failover if the only image available is the < 1.9 version.

The impact of this is major. Basically after an operator upgrades the control plane, the first update (change a member for example) to a load balancer on older amps will cause them to fail. A completely unrelated setting change on a load balancer causes it to fail.

This was found because my backend re-encryption test patches started failing after the ALPN patch merged and the amphora image default was still bionic.

With this change, the only impact is to users the explicitly specify HTTP/2 for backend pool connections, when running < 1.9 amphora, their connections will fall back to HTTP/1.1.

It also aligns exactly to the release note, "Support for new features requires an image update".

I forgot to also mention another issue with this approach. The API will happily validate, store in the database and return to the user the desired ALPN protocols which, though, may not be applied in the HAProxy configuration.

Yes.
This is after the user has got a response (because we can't talk to an amphora until after that), so we either fail the amphora, or remove the offending setting.
In this case, worst case is it will fall back to only HTTP/1.1 connections.
The release note should call out that for the new feature, a new amphora image is required.

/COMMIT_MSG.message: i've been playing with shrinking and overlapping shard ranges a few days now and do not understand the motivation or justification of this change

The trouble is when you've got the split-brain in a shard -- after you manually fix the shard ranges, you run into trouble if auto_shard is enabled. The root's sharded, so it's willing to look for shrinking candidates, which led to it expanding the acceptor's range to include the guy we're trying to get rid of. This, of course, means there's a new overlapping range: http://paste.openstack.org/show/795900/

My thinking is, whatever process is responsible for transitioning a shard range to shrinking should also be responsible for ensuring that the namespace is properly covered. And it should only need to think about that *at the point of transition* -- otherwise we need to take a much more holistic view when finding shrinking candidates, rather than the pairwise comparisons we do currently.

Longer term, we may need to take that holistic view so we can address overlapping shard ranges automatically -- but for right now I want to make sure we aren't going to make anything worse or more complicated.

swift/container/sharder.py.message:
OK, this is starting to make more sense for what's going on with the current probe test -- it won't resolve just by setting the unwanted shards to shrinking, because we only call this when the root is sharded (and in this probe test, it's still sharding). I should probably write a probe test with the split brain in a shard instead of the root.

It's worth noting that I've seen overlapping *active* shard ranges in the wild, which implies that the dueling leaders actually managed to fully shard. Still needs more investigation to repro.

Taking in all the relevant ranges into the shared db is doing a WORLD of good.  We limit shard_ranges with marker/end_marker; we should do this in ALL cases.  I don't see any negative side of merging "TMI" down to the shards and all the tests I have access to seem to agree.

Mainly I just hadn't looked that closely at the implications of doing that. I knew that shrinking ranges would have more than one shard range in them, but wasn't aware of any other states where we'd coded expecting that behavior. *Maybe* it'd be safe to put all shard ranges from the root into an ACTIVE or SHARDING shard... Things like the "send everything" approach in _update_root_container() are a little worrying, though.

OTOH, it'd be nice down in _move_objects() if fetching shard ranges was purely local. Hmm...
This logic makes me a little nervous -- the shrinking overlap won't be entirely included in any one shard range.
rather than skipping shrinking and raising errors on non-cleaving states - can we not just filter the states we want to process?

IDK -- I kinda like the protection afforded here. There are so many moving pieces even on the happy-path that I'd prefer to have sharding stop if the container isn't in a known-good state, rather than start moving us down some unknown path we haven't thought about yet.

I wonder if this should also ignore SHARDING ranges since SHRINKING ranges will transition to SHARDING so they can cleave...

Though at that point, we've nearly done the filtering you suggested above. *shrug*
hrm... I didn't notice this situation coming up since we don't include_own?

It happens in test_manage_shard_ranges_used_poorly -- after we manually fix the shard range states and run the replicators, we have to run the sharders repeatedly. In some earlier patchsets, it required 5 iterations to get it to settle, because the sharding root would need to wait for the shrinking shards to be marked as deleted before it could start making progress again.

(Come to think of it, warning's probably too noisy here -- info or even debug would be better.)

I'm starting to really wonder if this should only send

 [sr for sr in shard_ranges if own_shard_range.includes(sr)]
...but I guess we should still return True from _cleave() once we've done them both, so we'll trigger completion down here...
Hey, wait -- I updated the commit message with my plan, but forgot to update the code!

i want to do this everytime; it's especially useful when there's overlaps (such as shrinking or split-brain)

there's no down side I can see and having a single behavior in the shards for overlap is less complexity to keep in our head.

it seems like this is ALSO just logging a warning; i'm not sure why it's relevant to separate it from the block below...

... also no test

It's subtle, but the other one has a

 break

that means we stop processing any more shards. Whereas this carve-out lets us keep going.

This let me lower the number of times we run the sharders over in the probe test from 5 to 4 -- it used to be that we'd (probably) need to do one cycle to get all the shrinking guys to sharded/deleted before the sharding DB could start making progress, but now those can happen in the same cycle.

Also, this shouldn't be a warning now -- it's become expected behavior. Not sure whether to go with info or debug tho...

there's a bug fix here adding the '%s'

... no new test tho

Yup -- I probably wouldn't have noticed it except I'd

 tail -f /var/log/syslog | sed -e '/raceback/!d; s/#012/\n/g'

while running probe tests in a loop. Which reminds me, https://review.opendev.org/#/c/732996/ is still a thing...

doc/source/user/runner.rst.message:
From a usability point of view, I believe that the need to configure the things in this file (regardless of whether we have a file or use command line arguments, etc.) is a very large hurdle for users.  Especially the idea that they would need to figure out and set up something like site log storage.  That is, essentially, the only thing that makes the idea of "just run a Zuul" an impractical solution to the problem this stack is attempting to solve; so I think this needs to solve it.

I thought our earlier discussions of this included the idea of omitting post-run playbooks so that we wouldn't have to deal with this?

If we focus on that, most users won't have to add secrets to this.

It would also be great to figure out a way to drop connections, and to simplify nodes.

I think we need to focus on the use case of someone trying to iterate locally on a complex job.  They don't want to set up a Zuul environment, they just want to run the job's main playbooks.

Note that site log storage default to the first test node and most users don't have to add secrets.

Connections may be dropped if/when Source driver support anonymous access.

If configuration is deemed a very large hurdle for users, how do you envision the zuul-runner interface?
Perhaps we should seriously start looking into setting up a Zuul docker-compose configuration as an alternative.  "Just run Zuul" is a lot easier than it used to be.
Wouldn't using Zuul docker compose to reproduce a job needs more configuration?

releasenotes/notes/new-secure-rbac-defau.message:
nit: default roles and system-scope from ...

I like to be verbose in explaining that a persona is a role and scope combination, and that the secure RBAC work required adopting new scopes and applying roles consistently from keystone.

nit:

I recommend that we keep the term scope out of the persona itself since it's implied already (e.g., project member, system admin, project reader as opposed to project-scoped member, system-scoped admin, etc.)

Default roles and tokens provided by keystone are first-class constructs, but personas aren't. We're just using the term to classify a set of common use cases applied to role and scope permutations.

++

Thanks for putting this in the release note. Some might read this note (or even other notes for this work across OpenStack projects) as a lot of work and churn, but it's actually freeing up space to push more API functionality to end users safely. Calling that out in an example is excellent.

I like to include in the upgrade section a snippet that tells operators how they can view the new defaults. This is especially important for deployments who are overriding the default policies today for a specific use case. They'll want to see if the new defaults allow them to remove the policies they've been maintaining in their deployment.

We can add a section that says operators can use

  oslopolicy-sample-generator --namespace manila

to generate a sample of the new defaults and possibly compare with their current policies.

Also, we can link to keystone's default roles and persona documentation [0], keeping the common terminology in a single place.

This will serve as a primer for people who haven't heard of the system-scope concept, default roles, or what we're calling personas. It also gives them tips for finding out who is who in their deployment, which is useful for the necessary prerequisite auditing step of consuming this work.

[0] https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/admin/service-api-protection.html

Done.

Thanks, this will bother me to not fix, given Zuul's really quick with turn around for release notes fixes

agent.yaml.template.message: Please can we update the Monasca Agent documentation to make reference to these? sysinv/cgts-client/cgts-client/cgtsclien.message: Text here doesn't make sense. Fetching the tarball is done during application-upload.

I meant the download is part of application-upload, so a closer to what happens message would be:
"Will attempt downloading an app from {}."
"Will attempt downloading an app from remote URL '{}' during application-upload.\n"

No it doesn't.
Because the download might take too long, they implemented a "poor man's async/future":

They use a dummy database entry as a placeholder until the future download is finished.

Then they return here without any actual application upload taking place.

If you look at what happens when you run this (w/o these modifications) , the command (system application-upload) returns immediately with a message about a dummy application placeholder being uploaded to local repo.

This is not correct. What is going on is that the command launched an operation that might finish at a later time, after this utility terminates. That operations might succeed or might fail depending on whether it can or cannot finish downloading the remote tarball, which is done asynchronously from the current execution context of the cli utility.

This utility presumably performs application-upload and returns. But, in the case of external URL, it does not actually perform the application-upload. It returns before even the tarball is downloaded.

I mean I can change the message if another wording might be better, but the face is that the order of operations is fetch tarball, unpack it, verify it, generate (correct) db entries ...

This utility returns (success!) even before the tarball is downloaded.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
This change got me thinking:

At a high level, this shouldn't be an issue because deleting queue entries should only be done by one actor at a time.  We exepect schedulers to lock queues when they are processing them (and this is why we have pipeline queues, so the locks can be fine-grained).

And in this case, we also have one "owner" -- the winner of the github connection election.  However, that single owner has two threads, and the second one is changing the queue out from under the first.

This made me consider what happens when we have multiple schedulers and we stop this one while it's processing.  Right now, we stop the dispatching thread (the one that reads from zk), and then once it joins, we stop the forwarding thread (the one that deletes from zk).  Between those two periods, the second scheduler will be able to start its dispatching thread and will lack information about any in-progress events from the first scheduler.  We may double-forward events because of this.

Instead of trying to plug that hole too, maybe we can address that and the issue in this patch by moving all of the zk event handling back into one thread, so this behaves more like how we expect the rest of the system to behave: a single thread processing the event queue at a time.

We can still parallelize the work, but by keeping the acks in the original thread, we can ensure that at least from an outside perspective, the event queue has a single owner while it's being processed.

Should probably remove this or get an alternative from the D&I WG. I know its on the list of like.. words we want to avoid going forward because of its roots.

The query results weren't published because it was just informal research to try to see if we were on the right track with the terms identified. It was literally "plug the words into codesearch.opendev.org and see what shows up" anyway, nothing exciting in that regard. And I agree with Ghanshyam, cleanup via separate patches would also be entirely reasonable so as to not muddy the scope of unrelated content changes.

We did preliminary codesearch queries of various terms, including this one, mainly to determine the different contexts in which they were being used as well as rate at which they occur in our projects. That said, it's up to individual projects to decide what they're going to replace, with what, and when. The D&I WG isn't going to do mass replacement patches, nor do they have the time even if they wanted to.

This breaks the deployment if nova::compute::rbd class is defined AFTER nova::compute::libvirt class.

https://zuul.opendev.org/t/openstack/build/c987fa00e1af458392f92e81361c327c/log/logs/etc/nova/nova.conf.txt#3132
For example we see 

This parameter was used to set to rbd.

thanks for the comments, this part is not correct. So how do you think of it if I remove the hardcoded images_type value from nova::compute::rbd class but let user to configure the correct one?

As I mentioned in my second comment, that implementation is still concerning because it doesn't correctly make users aware of the change they should implement.

One option is to implement a validation logic in nova::compute::rbd to make it fail if the nova::compute::rbd is already defined and its imate_type parameter is not set to rbd. Please note that for this option we need to update puppet-openstack-integration first so that nova::compute::rbd is included before nova::compute::libvirt is included.

Another option is to make this parameter optional (defaults to undef and don't manage the parameter if it is set to undef).
Please use $::os_service_default here as you have documented
When you switch to $::os_service_default, just ad 'libvirt/image_type': vaolue => $images_type and remove the if condition below
We can't do this because it would cause a conflict with nova::compute::rbd which sets image_type='rbd'

manifests/type/airship-core/shared/catal.message:
I'm not sure that it makes sense to put all of this config into a new type-level catalogue:

1. most of this I think we expect to change infrequently from one type or site to another, so it may be better represented as a simple patch of the content below as part of the k8scontrol-ha function.  Let me know if I'm missing some reason that you think the whole block of config needs to be reconfigured frequently.

2. on the other hand, the IP addresses will typically need to be reconfigured very often - they'll typically be different from one site to another.  So those probably need to live in a site-level catalogue.  You could use substring replacement into the text below to accomplish this (similar to what we do when we inject IP addresses into cloud-init data).

Logically, this stuff could live in the existing NetworkingCatalogue, but that probably won't work, since that is defined in the airshipctl project (which knows nothing about this HA stuff).  Instead, can we define it in a new entrypoint here:
manifests/function/treasuremap-base-catalogues/networking-ha.yaml

And that could have contents along the lines of
...
spec:
  vrrp:
    kubernetes:
      interface: bond.51
      virtual_ipaddress: 10.23.25.102
    ingress:
      interface: bond.51
      virtual_ipaddress: 10.23.25.101

Note: the config above assumes that the other values (virtual_router_id, priority, advert_int) should stay the same between Airship sites; if that is incorrect then they could go into the catalogue too.
Thanks Matt for the detailed reply. I agree with your idea of having a function level networking-ha catalogue. I have made the related changes. Please let me know your comments.

Thanks Manoj, that helps.  I am still thinking that a more specific `networking-ha` catalogue would make sense.  Let me see if I can convince you :)

Normal kustomize patching and catalogues both have a place.  Patching is simpler to develop and understand, and can be used best when software just needs to be configured for different use cases.  I think the the "one, two, or more VIPs" configuration probably falls into that category -- different use cases / configurations.

Catalogues+Replacement are a good fit when you have the *same* configuration, except for a handful of type-specific (or site-specific), known values.  The IP addresses fit into this category for sure, and probably the bonds, but I would argue that other parts of the vrrpconfig do not.  Couple reasons:

1. if we want to change the *configuration* (not IPs) for vrrp, we'd have to make the same change across many site definitions.  E.g. if we need to tweak the kubeadmPreCommands or add additional configuration.
2. when the operator needs to craft the catalogue for a particular site, they'll have to look through it for the particular fields they need to change, making it a bit harder to create a new site, and introducing the opportunity for them to inadvertently change other things they shouldn't.

Putting it another way: if we ignored the catalogue stuff and just thought about normal patching, should the info be patched at the function level, type level, or the site level, or both?  I think both -- the general structure at either the function or type level, and the IPs/bonds at the site level.  Then if we ask ourselves what makes sense to put in a catalogue, I think the site-level stuff should be.  But patching the full config file into a catalogue and then replacing it into the KubeadmConfig doesn't seem to add benefit on top of patching the full config file into the KubeadmConfig.

Let me know if you disagree.

Thanks for the review comments. A little documentation on my part could have helped.

> I'm not sure that it makes sense to put all of this config into a new type-level catalogue:
> 
> 1. most of this I think we expect to change infrequently from one type or site to another, so it may be better represented as a simple patch of the content below as part of the k8scontrol-ha function.  Let me know if I'm missing some reason that you think the whole block of config needs to be reconfigured frequently.
> 
Manoj Alva : The type level catalogue is just a placeholder. When i tried introducing the new Variable catalogue, the validate_doc.sh put out an kustomize error for a missing plugin. So i had to put this. 
Patcset : 28


> 2. on the other hand, the IP addresses will typically need to be reconfigured very often - they'll typically be different from one site to another.  So those probably need to live in a site-level catalogue.  You could use substring replacement into the text below to accomplish this (similar to what we do when we inject IP addresses into cloud-init data).

Manoj Alva : Yes. This is accomplished by this patchset. The user has to just override the contents of the manifests/site/test-site/target/catalogue/kubeadmconfig.yaml and the changes will be taken care of. 

> 
> Logically, this stuff could live in the existing NetworkingCatalogue, but that probably won't work, since that is defined in the airshipctl project (which knows nothing about this HA stuff).  Instead, can we define it in a new entrypoint here:
> manifests/function/treasuremap-base-catalogues/networking-ha.yaml
> 
> And that could have contents along the lines of
> ...
> spec:
>   vrrp:
>     kubernetes:
>       interface: bond.51
>       virtual_ipaddress: 10.23.25.102
>     ingress:
>       interface: bond.51
>       virtual_ipaddress: 10.23.25.101
> 
> Note: the config above assumes that the other values (virtual_router_id, priority, advert_int) should stay the same between Airship sites; if that is incorrect then they could go into the catalogue too.

Manoj Alva : Yes first i tried using the network catalogue. But since the network catalogue is controlled via a CRD (living in airshipctl), i decided to make a new VariableCatalogue.
About the manifest mentioned above, this method will not be extensible in case which may require more than 2 VIPs or one VIP. The placeholders within the function get hardcoded (as in the case on my earlier patchsets). The main issue with the VRRP/Prekubecommands is that they are list within the manifest and i had difficulty in manipulating the placement. 
So my proposal is extensible to the extent that user has to just define the kubeadmconfig-catelogue at site level with what ever number of VIPs or commands, and the same will be copied into the final manifest.

Let me know if you have and questions.
Thanks

roles/add-build-sshkey/defaults/main.yam.message: Moving these from vars/ to defaults/ changes their precedence.  Is that required?  If not, I think I'd prefer to keep them in vars/ to make it more difficult to override the playbook author's intent.

Some of these arguments are passed to a shell that's run in a trusted context on the executor, so if we want to allow them to be overridable by untrusted projects, we need to be careful.  I have 2 suggestions:

1) Keep these all in vars/ and configure your base job to generate both types of keys (we may need to update this role to be able to run twice or (even better) generate both at once).  This has the advantage of being able to use both ECDSA and RSA nodes in the same job.

or

2) Keep most of these in vars/ but move the algorithm and key size parameters to defaults so they can be overridden.  Also perform some sanity checking of the supplied values so that people can't supply shell escape sequences or extra ssh args, etc (probably just test they're in a known set of values).

I think I prefer #1 since it makes this role able to accomodate the situation of a mixed set of nodes.  I'd make size+algorithm a list like:

zuul_ssh_key_types:
  - algorithm: rsa
    size: 3072
  - algorithm: ecdsa
    size: 512

This is a good point, it could potentially pose a security risk if it was overridable as a default from an untrusted repo or otherwise outside the repository where the playbook is defined. I'm not quite certain I can come up with an exploit scenario off the top of my head, but I agree it's a case of things we might want to try to be safer by default on.
Not all of our nodes support ECDSA. So some of our jobs use ECDSA ans some RSA. We have to keep these vaiables in defaults folder, so that we can override them at job runtime.

I think the issue is, if we keep it in vars, we will not be able to override them at all (I am testing this now). Here is why I say that:

  In general, Ansible gives precedence to variables that were defined more recently, more actively, and with more explicit scope. Variables in the the defaults folder inside a role are easily overridden. Anything in the vars directory of the role overrides previous versions of that variable in the namespace.

https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/user_guide/playbooks_variables.html#understanding-variable-precedence

Which means, we likely need to do number #2
testing with include_role, and vars I think we are okay with moving back to vars/main.yaml.  Running the roles twice also worked as expected.

deployment/timemaster/timemaster-baremet.message:
Wtih this implementation, it will accept only the role-specific parameters and it will not accept global parameters. 

Valid Example
-------------
parameter_defaults:
  ComputeSriovParameters:
    PTPMessageTransport: "..."
    PTPInterfaces: "..."


Invalid Example
---------------
parameter_defaults:
  PTPMessageTransport: "..."
  PTPInterfaces: "..."


First example will apply only to the provided role (Computesriov), but the later will apply the parameters to all the roles which includes the "OS::TripleO::Timemaster" service. Is this the intended behavior?

I would recomment to merge the global and role-specific via a resource as like other parameters using this merging code:

  RoleParametersValue:
    type: OS::Heat::Value
    properties:
      type: json
      value:
        map_replace:
          - map_replace:
            - tripleo_ptp4l_interface: PtpInterface
              tripleo_ptp4l_conf_network_transport: PtpMessageTransport
            - values: {get_param: [RoleParameters]}
          - values:
              PtpInterface: {get_param: PtpInterface}
              PtpMessageTransport: {get_param: PtpMessageTransport}

Once it is merged, it can be used as below in here:

        ptp_interfaces: {get_attr: [RoleParametersValue, value, tripleo_ptp4l_interface]}
        ptp_transport: {get_attr: [RoleParametersValue, value, tripleo_ptp4l_conf_network_transport]}
Yes these are role specific parameters. Since, Controllers dont need them, making them global like chrony (where chrony used by controller node as well) wont be good option. What do you think?
Shouldn't this be in the role itself?
Sure, will add them as part of triple-ansible role
You're also missing the RoleParametersValue structure to enable the role specific nature of these vars. See deployment/iscsid/iscsid-container-puppet.yaml as an example

This is not how you use role parameters. You need to have the RoleParametersValue structure as a heat output. See the iscsi file as an example

zuul.d/multinode-jobs.yaml.message:
The possible problem that can be is "zuul can't freeze the tree" - when some job depends on content-provider, but content-provider doesn't run because of irrelevant files.
Even if you set here exactly same irrelevant files for multinode jobs and content-providers, we still may have problem:
usually we run both standalone and multinode templates on same patch, maybe even upgrades template as well. And each of these templates has its own content provider and its irrelevant files. But eventually only one content-provider job will run on a patch. And it will run with some of "irrelevant-files" settings, not with all of them (it's overridden, not merged). And in this case we might hit again the case when content-provider won't run and zuul will fail.

thanks

what you tried to describe above is the type of scenario i was imagining.

BUT

the content-provider-ussuri/victoria/train are only used in this template and in the upgrades layouts.

ironic/common/pxe_utils.py.message:
As i understand this has to be installed on the conductor node. The conductor node can be any OS based. Suppose the conductor node is Ubuntu based, and the OS beind deployed is RHEL. When you run the ksvalidator on conductor node on the kickstart file, will it verify the kickstart syntaxes against Ubuntu OS or RHEL OS? 
The Ubuntu OS kickstart and RHEL OS kickstart are similar, but there are differences and some of the kickstart options which work on RHEL, do not work on Ubuntu.

Thanks for the question. ksvalidator can be installed on both ubuntu and RHEL. However the tool willvaldiate against RHEL releases ( deploy OS). I do not think this tool will validate kickstart files generated for ubuntu release. We have called out this in the scope of the SPEC https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/ironic-specs/+/748503/9/specs/approved/anaconda-deploy-interface.rst#117

I think you didnt get my query well. To make my query clear, breaking it into different questions:

- Where is this tool going to be installed? Is it in the deploy OS? or the conductor node?
- If ksvalidator has to be installed on conductor node, then it will validate the kickstart for the OS where ksvalidator is installed. The tool cannot validate the kickstart for RHEL if it is installed on Ubuntu node.

> Where is this tool going to be installed? Is it in the deploy OS? or the conductor node?
Conductor node.

>  The tool cannot validate the kickstart for RHEL if it is installed on Ubuntu node.

This is not true. The tool can validate RHEL kickstart files on an ubuntu node. In fact the tool can *only* validate kickstart files generated for RHEL. The tool does not support validating kickstart files generated for ubuntu. But this driver does not support ubuntu/debian as mentioned in the SPEC.

Here is ksvalidator tool on ubuntu http://paste.openstack.org/show/803877/

I have used 'ksvalidator -l' to list supported releases. As you can see it only lists RHEL (RHELx), Fedora(Fxx) and old Fedora Core (FCx) as supported kickstart versions. It also lists "DEVEL" as one of the kickstart versions, DEVEL here means lastest kickstart development version of kickstart.

ironic/drivers/modules/pxe_base.py.message: Should this be part of the pxe interface validation or the deploy interface validation? Is there a specific reason you put it here?

This is a good question. The kickstart template is not fetched until the line#240 (pxe_utils.cache_ramdisk_kernel) so we can't validate it until the template is fetched. We could potentially validate the template in pxe interface validation, if the template is fetched before the validation method is called.
